alt_statements.statement: I see the litter all over the streets and parks where I take my kids, and it makes me angry because everyone deserves a clean, safe place to live and play. The city should put more trash cans everywhere, give real fines to people who litter, and use that money for neighborhood cleanups and education in schools so kids learn early to respect public spaces. We also need community clean-up days with support from the city, so families and neighbors can work together and feel proud of where we live.

I think there should be more trash cans everywhere and big, colorful signs that remind people to throw their garbage away, because God wants us to take care of His creation. Grown-ups should get tickets if they litter on purpose, but kids could have to help clean up so they learn not to do it again. Schools and churches could also have clean-up days so we all feel proud of keeping our town neat.

As someone who’s spent a life caring for people’s health, I see clean public spaces as part of basic community well-being, so we need strong anti-littering policies that actually get enforced, not just signs people ignore. Cities should combine meaningful fines with plenty of trash and recycling bins, public education in schools and community centers, and programs that pay or reward folks—especially low-income and disabled residents—for helping with cleanups. I also support holding corporations responsible for excess packaging and waste, because everyday people shouldn’t shoulder all the blame while big companies profit.

As a mom raising kids here in Oregon, I think preventing littering starts with personal responsibility and respect for our community, not just more government rules. We should have plenty of trash and recycling cans in parks and public areas, and schools should teach kids early on to clean up after themselves. Fines for littering should be enforced consistently, but families, churches, and local groups also need to set a good example and organize clean-up days so children see that caring for God’s creation is part of our everyday life.

As someone who grew up in a time when we took more personal responsibility for our surroundings, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and clear expectations. We should have meaningful fines for littering, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and straightforward public signage, but also teach respect for our communities in schools and churches. Local volunteer clean-up days can help people feel ownership of their neighborhoods, instead of always expecting the government to fix everything.

I think the best way to prevent littering is to make it really easy for people to do the right thing, like having more trash and recycling bins that are clearly labeled and regularly emptied. Schools and churches could also teach more about taking care of God’s creation and our community, so people feel responsible instead of seeing it as someone else’s problem. I also believe in having fines for people who litter on purpose, because there should be consequences when you knowingly make public places dirty for everyone else.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors sketching and finding inspiration in parks and city streets, it breaks my heart to see trash scattered where beauty should be. I think we need a mix of practical steps—like plenty of accessible trash and recycling bins, regular clean-up crews, and meaningful fines for repeat offenders—along with public art and education campaigns that make people feel proud of keeping shared spaces clean. I’d especially love to see community-led projects and school programs that involve kids in caring for their neighborhoods, because when people feel a sense of ownership and connection, they’re far less likely to litter in the first place.

As someone who supervises food service in a state facility, I see every day how much of littering is about systems, not just personal behavior. The most effective policies combine plentiful, clearly marked trash and recycling bins with real enforcement of fines, and they should require businesses—especially food service—to take responsibility for the waste their products generate. I also support funding public education campaigns, including in Korean and other community languages, that connect cleanliness to shared pride in our neighborhoods. Keeping public spaces clean is a community obligation, and government has a duty to lead with strong, fair, and well-communicated rules.

As someone who spends a lot of time out and about for work and exploring new places, I think strong anti-littering policies matter both for basic public health and for simple respect for shared spaces. The best approach is a mix of clear fines that are actually enforced, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and public education that makes not littering feel like a community norm, not just a rule. I’d also support holding businesses more accountable for trash generated around their properties and investing in city jobs that keep public spaces clean, instead of just relying on volunteers to pick up after everyone else.

As someone who spends a lot of time sketching in parks and walking around my neighborhood, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and smart public policy. We need plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, consistent fines that are actually enforced, and community-driven clean-up programs that make people feel pride and ownership in their public spaces. I also believe in using art—murals, creative signage, youth art projects—to visually remind people that these shared spaces matter and are worth respecting.

As someone who takes pride in keeping my home and garden tidy, I believe our public spaces deserve the same respect, and that starts with personal responsibility and community standards. Clear rules, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and meaningful fines for littering all matter, but so does teaching young people—through schools, churches, and community groups—that caring for God’s creation is part of good citizenship. I’d also like to see more neighborhood clean‑up days and visible recognition for businesses and groups that keep their areas clean, so setting a good example becomes the norm.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime believing in personal responsibility and pride in one’s community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a combination of clear rules and real consequences. We should enforce fines for littering, but we also need to invest in plenty of trash and recycling bins, community clean-up days through churches and civic groups, and education that teaches respect for shared spaces. From my perspective, people are more likely to take care of their town when they feel ownership and see their neighbors doing the same.

As someone who grew up in New York and still cares deeply about my neighborhood and the people who live in it, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public services and shared responsibility. Cities should provide plenty of well-maintained trash and recycling bins, regular pickup, and clear signage, but there also need to be consistent fines for people and businesses who keep making a mess. At the same time, education—especially in schools and community centers—should stress how littering harms everyone, from working folks like me to the next generation, and how keeping our streets clean is part of treating each other with dignity and respect.

At my age, I’ve seen how much pride people used to take in keeping their streets and parks clean, and I think we need to get back to that sense of personal responsibility. Stronger fines for littering are important, but so is teaching children and reminding adults—through churches, community groups, and local campaigns—that caring for our shared spaces is a moral duty. I’d also like to see more trash cans and community clean‑up days, so neighbors work together and feel accountable for the places we all use.

As someone who spends a lot of time out on the road and in neighborhoods delivering packages, I see firsthand how much litter can pile up and drag a community down. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong, consistently enforced fines and practical measures like more trash and recycling bins where people actually need them, plus school and church-based education that teaches kids respect for shared spaces. Local governments should partner with families, churches, and small businesses to sponsor clean-up days and “adopt-a-street” programs so people feel personal responsibility for their surroundings. When we treat our streets and parks like our own front yard, we’re much less likely to trash them.

As someone who spends a lot of time performing in parks, plazas, and other public spaces, I see firsthand how litter can drag down the energy of a place that’s supposed to bring people together. The best policies combine plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins with real education—especially around events—so people feel responsible for the spaces they use, plus meaningful fines for repeat offenders. I’d also love to see cities partner with local artists and musicians to design creative anti-litter campaigns that speak to community pride, not just punishment. Clean public spaces are a matter of respect—for our neighbors, our environment, and the shared stages where we all live our lives.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is to make personal responsibility the norm again, backed up with real, consistently enforced fines. Cities and towns should provide enough trash cans and dumpsters, especially in busy areas and parks, but people need to be held accountable when they just toss garbage on the ground. I’d also like to see more community clean‑up days and school programs that teach kids pride in their town so they grow up respecting shared spaces instead of expecting the government to pick up after them.

When we go to the park or church, I don’t like seeing trash on the ground because it makes the place look dirty and not nice to play in. I think grown-ups should put more trash cans around and teach kids, like me and my brothers and sisters, to always throw things away and help clean up together as a family.

I don’t like seeing trash on the ground because it makes parks and sidewalks look ugly and hurts animals, and I don’t want to draw pictures of places that are dirty. I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins everywhere, and grown-ups should teach kids at school and church to always throw things away and maybe even have fun games or prizes for keeping places clean.

As someone who cares a lot about the environment and grew up seeing how trash piles up in parks and on streets, I think the best way to stop littering is a mix of strict rules and real education. There should be more trash and recycling bins everywhere, higher fines that actually get enforced, and school and community programs that show how littering harms our neighborhoods, especially the places where kids play. I’d also love to see incentives, like discounts or rewards for people who join clean-up events or consistently use reusable containers. Making clean, trash-free spaces a shared community goal would help people feel proud of where they live instead of just seeing it as someone else’s problem.

I think there should be more trash cans and recycling bins in parks and on the streets so people don’t just throw stuff on the ground. At church and at school, they tell us God wants us to take care of His creation, so we should have signs that remind people not to litter and maybe make kids do fun projects about keeping our neighborhoods clean.

As someone who works in a school and cares deeply about setting a good example for young people, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a combination of clear rules and consistent community expectations. There should be visible, convenient trash and recycling bins, along with fines for repeat offenders, but also regular community clean-up days and school-led education that teach respect for shared spaces as part of our responsibility to one another and to God’s creation.

As someone who walks to school and spends time in parks and libraries, I think the best way to prevent littering is to mix strict enforcement with real education. There should be more visible trash and recycling bins, higher fines that are actually enforced, and school programs that show how litter hurts our neighborhoods and the environment. I also think community clean-up events, especially in working-class and Latino communities like mine, would help people feel more responsible and proud of where we live.

As a retired public school teacher, I can’t help but see littering as a failure to teach basic respect—for our neighbors, our communities, and the environment we all share. The best policies combine clear fines and consistent enforcement with lots of public education, especially for kids, plus practical solutions like more trash and recycling bins and organized community clean‑ups. I’d also like to see corporations held more responsible for excessive packaging and waste, instead of putting all the blame on individuals.

As someone who spends a lot of peaceful time in my garden and values well-kept public spaces, I believe strong anti-littering policies are essential, but they have to be paired with practical solutions. That means plentiful, clearly marked trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and public education—especially in schools—about our shared responsibility to keep communities clean. I’d also like to see local governments partner with community groups and businesses to sponsor regular clean-up days, because when people feel ownership of their parks and streets, they’re less likely to trash them.

I think the best way to stop littering is to hit people in the wallet with real fines and actually enforce them, not just put up “no littering” signs nobody cares about. Cities should also put more trash and recycling bins in parks and on streets so people don’t have an excuse, and schools should teach kids how trash hurts our neighborhoods and the environment. If we want cleaner, safer places to hang out, everyone has to be held responsible for their own mess instead of expecting someone else to clean it up.

As someone who cares deeply about both community and the environment, I believe the most effective way to prevent littering is a combination of clear regulations, meaningful fines, and strong public education campaigns that start in schools and reach people in multiple languages, including Spanish. Well-placed trash and recycling bins, regular cleaning, and visible enforcement send the message that shared spaces are truly valued. I also support involving local businesses and neighborhood groups in “adopt-a-park” or “adopt-a-street” programs, because when people feel ownership, they’re far less likely to treat public spaces like dumping grounds.

As someone who spends a lot of time outside, both gardening and walking around my neighborhood, I find it heartbreaking how much trash ends up in our parks and streets. I’d like to see stronger local regulations with real fines for littering, paired with more public trash and recycling bins and community clean-up programs that make people feel invested in their own spaces. We also need more environmental education in schools and public campaigns that frame keeping our shared spaces clean as a basic civic responsibility, not just a personal choice. To me, respecting the environment is an extension of respecting each other.

Working in community outreach, I’ve seen that the most effective way to prevent littering is to combine practical solutions—like plentiful trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and consistent city maintenance—with strong community education and engagement. We should invest in public campaigns, school programs, and volunteer cleanups that make people feel responsible for shared spaces, and back that up with reasonable fines for repeat offenders so it’s clear that respecting our environment is a basic civic duty.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors with my family, I think strong anti-littering policies really matter—not just fines, but making it easy for people to do the right thing. That means more trash and recycling bins in parks, on sidewalks, and at bus stops, plus clear signage and public campaigns that teach kids early on to respect shared spaces. I’d also support community clean‑up programs and holding businesses accountable for excess packaging and waste, since big companies contribute a lot to what ends up on our streets.

As someone who spends his days thinking about how environments shape behavior—especially for kids—I believe the best anti-littering policies combine clear rules with constant education. We should pair visible, well-maintained trash and recycling infrastructure with meaningful fines, but also integrate environmental stewardship into school curricula and community programs so that not littering becomes part of our shared moral habit, not just a legally enforced obligation.

At my age, I’ve watched parks and sidewalks slowly fill with trash, and it breaks my heart because public spaces are one of the few places everyone can share equally. I believe the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public education, especially with children, plenty of conveniently placed trash and recycling bins, and meaningful fines that are actually enforced. We should also invest in community cleanup programs and volunteer days, because when people feel ownership and pride in their neighborhoods, they’re far less likely to throw garbage on the ground.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is a mix of personal responsibility and some common-sense rules. We should have clear fines for littering and actually enforce them, but also make it easy to do the right thing with plenty of trash and recycling bins in public areas. I’d like to see more local volunteer clean-up efforts too, especially involving churches and community groups, because when people take pride in their town, they’re less likely to trash it.

I think the best way to stop people from littering is to make it both easier and cooler not to litter, like putting more trash and recycling bins in parks and streets and having student-led clean‑up events. There should still be fines for people who litter on purpose, but schools and communities should focus more on teaching why protecting nature and wildlife matters, so people actually care instead of just being scared of getting in trouble.

As someone who spends his days caring for people’s health, I see clean public spaces as a basic public health and dignity issue, not just an aesthetic one. The best policies to prevent littering combine practical measures—like plentiful trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and consistent fines—with education that appeals to our shared responsibility for one another and for the environment. I’d like to see community service, rather than just monetary penalties, for repeat offenders, so people directly experience the impact of their actions. Public campaigns that highlight how litter disproportionately harms poorer neighborhoods also align with my belief in social justice and our moral duty to protect the most vulnerable.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and working on community art projects, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart policy and cultural change: clear bins everywhere, strong fines that are actually enforced, and well-designed public spaces that people feel proud of. I’d also love to see more creative approaches—like artful signage, community mural projects about the environment, and youth programs—that make people feel personally connected to keeping shared spaces clean.

As someone who values individual responsibility but also believes in effective public systems, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of smart design and clear accountability. Cities should invest in well-placed, clearly marked trash and recycling bins and use data (like sensors or periodic audits) to see where litter problems are worst, then adjust infrastructure and cleaning schedules accordingly. At the same time, there should be meaningful, consistently enforced fines for littering, paired with public awareness campaigns that appeal to community pride and shared responsibility for keeping our spaces clean.

At seventy-six, I’ve lived long enough to see how carelessly we treat the commons, and it pains me every time I see a park or sidewalk strewn with trash instead of leaves or petals. The most effective way to prevent littering, in my view, is a combination of strict enforcement with meaningful fines, ubiquitous, well-designed waste and recycling bins, and sustained public education—especially with children—that frames caring for public spaces as both a civic duty and a moral obligation. Public art and community projects that transform once-littered corners into places of beauty can also shift behavior; people are far less likely to deface what they feel some pride and ownership in.

As someone who works in restaurants and sees firsthand how much waste we generate, I think strong anti-littering policies need to be paired with better infrastructure and education, not just fines. Cities should invest in more public trash and recycling bins, require businesses to use eco-friendly packaging, and run awareness campaigns about how litter affects local communities and the environment. I’m pretty social and out in public a lot, and it’s obvious that when spaces are clean and bins are easy to find, people are more likely to do the right thing.

If you want people to stop littering, you hit it from two sides: personal responsibility and real enforcement. We need clear rules, plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins, and fines that are actually enforced so folks think twice before tossing something on the ground. I’ve spent my life around transportation systems, and when you keep a place clean and hold people accountable, most will respect it—let it slide, and standards fall fast. Public spaces are shared property, and it’s on each of us to treat them with the same care we’d want for our own backyard.

Living on a modest income and spending much of my time in parks and around theaters, I see how litter can really spoil spaces that should feel welcoming to everyone. I think we need a mix of strong fines and clear signage, lots more trash and recycling bins, and community-based clean-up programs that involve kids and families so they grow up respecting shared spaces. Public arts campaigns—murals, posters, maybe even student projects—could also help change attitudes and make keeping our streets clean feel like a point of pride, not just a rule.

Living in a working-class neighborhood and raising kids here, I see how litter makes a place feel like nobody cares, and that’s not the message I want my children to grow up with. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of real consequences, like fines and community service, and making it easier to do the right thing by having plenty of trash and recycling bins and regular clean-up crews. Schools and local programs should also teach kids early about taking pride in where you live, because when people feel ownership of their community, they’re less likely to trash it.

As someone who spends a lot of time outside with my kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of common-sense rules, visible trash and recycling bins, and consistent fines that are actually enforced. Public spaces should be kept clean not just by government crews, but by teaching kids in schools and churches to take pride in their community and pick up after themselves. I’d rather see money go into simple, practical measures like better signage, frequent bin emptying, and local cleanup events than into big flashy campaigns that don’t change daily habits.

As someone who spends a lot of time thinking about health and cleanliness, both in mouths and in our community, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of education, convenience, and accountability. Cities should provide plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, run ongoing public awareness campaigns starting with kids, and enforce reasonable fines for littering so people take it seriously. I’d also love to see more community clean-up days that families can participate in together, because when you help take care of a place, you’re less likely to trash it.

As someone who walks city streets every day and pays attention to how our shared spaces look and feel, I think the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, smart design, and community pride. We need more trash and recycling bins where people actually are, strong fines that are consistently enforced, and public campaigns—especially in schools—that frame keeping our parks and sidewalks clean as a matter of civic duty and respect for each other. I’d also like to see local and federal agencies fund public art, murals, and community projects in plazas and bus stops, because when people feel a place is cared for and beautiful, they’re less likely to trash it.

As someone who cares deeply about keeping my community clean and setting a good example for my kids, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of clear rules, meaningful fines, and plenty of convenient trash and recycling bins. We also need strong public education—especially in schools and through local volunteer clean-up events—so people see clean public spaces as a shared responsibility, not just a city job. As a social liberal, I support using policy and public investment together, so it’s both easy and expected to do the right thing.

As someone who takes pride in her community and enjoys walking through clean parks and neighborhoods, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and firm consequences. We should have clear laws with meaningful fines for littering, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and local volunteer clean-up efforts through churches and civic groups to reinforce shared values of respect and stewardship.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and takes pride in keeping my community clean, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and real consequences. Cities should put more trash and recycling bins in busy public areas, but they should also enforce strict fines and community service for people who still choose to litter. I’d also support school and church-led clean-up days to teach younger folks respect for shared spaces and good stewardship of what God’s given us.

As a nurse and a mom, I see firsthand how a clean environment impacts both public health and the example we set for our kids, so I believe we need a mix of personal responsibility and firm, consistent enforcement to prevent littering. Clear rules with meaningful fines, plenty of well-maintained trash and recycling bins, and community clean-up efforts led by local churches, schools, and civic groups strike the right balance between accountability and community pride.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors watching birds and caring about local ecosystems, I think the best policies to prevent littering combine clear rules, real enforcement, and strong public education. Well-placed trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and community service requirements for violators can change behavior, but they should be paired with campaigns that show how litter harms wildlife and our shared environment. I’d also support funding local “adopt-a-park” or “adopt-a-trail” programs so residents, including people like me who love nature, have ownership and a say in keeping public spaces clean.

As someone who cares about both my neighborhood and practical solutions, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and making it easy to do the right thing. Cities should invest in plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, impose meaningful fines for littering, and reinvest that revenue into community clean-up programs and education. I’d also like to see more volunteer-driven cleanup events and school programs that build a sense of shared responsibility, because people are less likely to trash a place they feel connected to.

En mi opinión, para evitar la basura en las calles se necesitan más botes bien colocados y limpiezas regulares, pero también multas claras para quien tire basura a propósito. Como alguien que trabaja duro y casi no tiene tiempo libre, me molesta ver los parques y las aceras sucias cuando salgo con la familia. También sería bueno que en las escuelas y en la comunidad se enseñe más respeto por los espacios públicos, porque si todos ponemos un poco de nuestra parte, el barrio se ve mejor y nos sentimos más orgullosos de donde vivimos.

As someone who manages a retail operation and spends a lot of time outdoors hiking, I see firsthand how much litter can degrade both our neighborhoods and natural spaces. I think the most effective approach is a mix of strong public investment—more trash and recycling bins, frequent pickup, and well-designed public spaces—combined with meaningful fines for repeat offenders and consistent enforcement. We should also fund educational campaigns, especially for kids, that connect keeping our shared spaces clean with civic responsibility and environmental stewardship. I’m comfortable paying a bit more in local taxes or business fees if it means cleaner, more livable communities for my family and customers.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling bins in places where people actually hang out, like parks and bus stops, so it’s easy to throw stuff away. Schools and communities should also teach kids why littering hurts animals and nature—kind of like a real-life quest to protect our world—so people feel responsible instead of just scared of getting a fine.

As a teacher, I see every day that the best way to prevent littering starts with education and clear community expectations—kids and adults alike need to learn that caring for our shared spaces is a basic civic duty. I support strong local policies like plenty of well-marked trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines for repeat offenders, and community service clean-up requirements, paired with school-based environmental programs so children grow up seeing nature as something to protect, not trash.

As someone who’s active in my community and cares deeply about shared spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public education, plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, and consistent fines that are actually enforced. I’d love to see cities partner with schools, synagogues, and neighborhood groups to organize clean-up days and art projects that make people proud of their parks and streets, because when people feel ownership and see beauty in a space, they’re less likely to trash it.

I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and practical solutions, like more clearly marked trash and recycling bins in parks and shopping areas. I’d also support stricter fines for people who litter, because it’s not fair for taxpayers and volunteers to constantly clean up after others. Community clean‑up days and school programs can help teach kids and families to take pride in keeping our neighborhoods and outdoor spaces clean for everyone, including our grandkids.

I don’t like seeing trash on the ground where I play, because it makes the park and church yard look yucky and unsafe. Grown-ups should put more trash and recycling bins everywhere and teach kids with stories and pictures about putting rubbish where it belongs, and maybe give out little prizes or stickers when people help clean up. If everyone, especially adults, shows they care for God’s world by not littering, it will stay nice for kids like me to run and play.

I don’t like seeing trash on the ground when I play outside because it makes the trees and grass look sad and dirty. I think there should be lots of trash and recycling cans everywhere, and grown-ups should teach kids at school and church that God wants us to take care of the Earth. If people litter, maybe they should have to help clean up the park so they learn not to do it again.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is a mix of personal responsibility and real consequences. Put more trash cans where people actually walk, make the rules clear with signs, and hand out meaningful fines to folks who throw their garbage on the ground. We shouldn’t need the government to babysit us on something this basic, but if people won’t act right, then enforcing the law is the next step. Keeping our streets, parks, and roads clean is just good manners and respect for our community.

As someone who spends a lot of time hiking and watching birds, I hate seeing trash scattered along trails and roadsides, and I think personal responsibility has to be the foundation of any anti-litter policy. Local governments should enforce fines for littering and actually follow through, but they should also make it easy to do the right thing by keeping plenty of trash and recycling bins in parks and public areas. I’d rather see community-driven cleanups, school education, and businesses taking some responsibility for the waste their products create than relying on more bureaucracy or new taxes.

Working in a school, I see every day how much cleaner and safer a place feels when everyone takes responsibility for their trash, so I think strong anti-littering policies matter. We need more trash and recycling bins in public spaces, clear signs, and real fines that are actually enforced, but we also need to teach kids early—at school and at home—about respecting our communities and the people who clean them. I’d like to see cities invest in community clean-up programs and jobs too, so keeping our neighborhoods clean is something we do together, not just something we punish after the fact.

I think the best way to stop littering is to put more trash and recycling bins where people actually hang out, like parks, skate spots, and bus stops, and make sure they get emptied so they don’t overflow. Schools and cities should also run more hands-on projects, like clean-up days or contests, so kids my age actually see how much trash builds up and feel responsible for keeping places nice. If people get caught littering on purpose, there should be fines or mandatory clean-up hours, because it’s not fair when a few lazy people ruin public spaces for everyone else.

I think there should be way more trash cans and recycling bins in parks and on streets, so people don’t have an excuse to drop stuff on the ground. Adults should have to pay a fine if they litter on purpose, and schools should teach kids why litter hurts animals and nature. If people knew a duck or squirrel might eat their trash and get sick, they’d probably think twice before throwing it on the ground.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and takes pride in working with my hands, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public policies and community responsibility. That means more public trash and recycling bins, meaningful fines that are actually enforced, and well-funded public education campaigns in both English and Spanish so everyone understands the impact of litter on our neighborhoods and environment. I’d also like to see programs that reward community cleanups and partnerships with local businesses, because when people feel ownership over shared spaces, they’re less likely to trash them in the first place.

As someone who spends a lot of time walking between patients’ homes and volunteering at neighborhood events, I see how litter directly affects both community pride and health. The best policies combine strong, consistently enforced fines for littering with practical supports like more public trash and recycling bins, clear signage in multiple languages, and well-funded community clean-up programs. I’d also like to see schools and local governments partner on education campaigns that frame keeping streets clean as a shared responsibility, not just a personal choice. When people feel ownership of their public spaces, backed by fair but firm rules, they’re much less likely to treat them like a dumping ground.

As someone who spends a lot of time in parks, streets, and venues performing, I see litter as a sign that we’ve stopped feeling connected to the spaces we share. The most effective policies, in my view, combine strict enforcement and real penalties with practical tools—plenty of visible bins, bottle-deposit systems, and clear signage—plus arts-driven public campaigns that make caring for our environment feel like a shared, creative responsibility. I’d also support requiring event organizers and businesses to have litter plans and clean-up accountability, so the burden doesn’t just fall on underfunded city crews. When people see that public spaces are treated with respect and beauty, they’re far less likely to trash them.

I may be old-fashioned, but I think the best way to stop littering is to teach respect for our surroundings at home and in the community, starting with the family and local churches or temples. People should face real fines and have to do community clean-up if they throw trash on the ground, and cities should put more trash cans where folks actually walk. Keeping public spaces clean is part of personal responsibility and discipline, and it also honors the earth, which my Buddhist faith teaches me we should care for, not treat like a dumping ground.

I think the best way to prevent littering is to make it really easy for people to throw stuff away properly, like having more trash and recycling bins in parks, on streets, and near schools. There should also be clear signs and some fines for people who litter on purpose, plus school projects or community clean‑up days so kids like me grow up caring about keeping our neighborhoods clean.

As someone who cares about my community and spends a lot of time outside and around people, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and positive community culture. Cities should put out more trash and recycling bins, issue real fines for littering, and invest in public education campaigns—especially in schools and on social media—that frame clean streets as a shared responsibility. I’d also support volunteer clean‑up days organized through churches and local groups, because when people actually help clean their neighborhood, they’re less likely to trash it again.

At my age, I’ve watched our parks and streets change, and I know that the most effective way to prevent littering is a mix of good education and smart, fair rules. Clear signage, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and modest fines—actually enforced—send a message, but we also need school and community programs that teach people, especially children, to respect shared spaces and the environment. I’d also like to see local governments partner with neighborhood groups to organize cleanups and celebrate those efforts publicly, so not littering feels like a shared community value rather than just a law to avoid breaking.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime in a profession built on order and accountability, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement and clear personal responsibility. We should have meaningful fines that are actually enforced, plenty of well-maintained trash and recycling bins, and community clean-up programs that remind people this is our shared space, not someone else’s problem. Public campaigns that appeal to pride in our neighborhoods—rather than feel-good slogans—would go a long way toward changing behavior.

Working in restaurants, I see every day how much waste we create, and it bothers me when that trash ends up on the street instead of in the right bin. The best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict fines, plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling cans, and strong public education that makes people feel responsible for their neighborhood. I’d also like to see businesses held more accountable for the packaging they use, pushing them toward compostable or reusable options so there’s less junk to toss in the first place.

At my age, I’ve seen how cleaner streets and parks make people prouder of their neighborhoods, and I believe preventing litter starts with strong community education and convenient trash and recycling bins everywhere. Fines are important, but they work best when combined with outreach in multiple languages, like Spanish, and school and community-center programs that teach respect for shared spaces. As someone who volunteers locally, I’d also like to see organized clean-up days and incentives for businesses to keep their storefronts clean, so everyone feels responsible for the places we share.

As someone who spends a lot of time outside gardening and walking around my neighborhood, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of common-sense rules and real accountability. We need plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, clear signage, and fines that are actually enforced—not just on paper. But we also need community clean-up days, school programs, and local campaigns that make people feel responsible for the spaces we all share. When folks see their neighbors caring for a park or sidewalk, they’re a lot less likely to treat it like a dumping ground.

As someone who spends long hours working and then tries to unwind by taking my kids to parks and public spaces, it really frustrates me to see trash everywhere. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement with real fines, plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, and visible public service campaigns that remind people we all share these spaces. I’d also support school-based programs that teach kids early about caring for the environment, because they bring those habits home and influence their parents too.

As someone who was raised to respect God’s creation and my neighbors, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility and firm consequences. We should teach kids and adults alike, in schools, churches, and community groups, that caring for our streets and parks is a moral duty, not just a rule. At the same time, we need clear laws and real fines for littering, and the money from those fines should go right back into keeping our communities clean and beautiful.

As someone who spends a lot of time gardening and watching birds, I see firsthand how litter harms wildlife and makes our shared spaces less enjoyable. I think the best policies combine practical solutions—like plenty of well-placed trash and recycling bins and consistent cleanup efforts—with meaningful fines for repeat offenders and public education that starts in schools and continues in the community. If people understand the impact of their actions and see that clean spaces are the norm, they’re more likely to take responsibility. This doesn’t need to be heavy-handed, just firm, fair, and focused on keeping our environment healthy for everyone.

As a mom raising my child in a dense city neighborhood, I really want cleaner streets and parks, but I don’t think it happens just by scolding people—we need a mix of smart policy and community responsibility. Clear rules with real fines for littering, plenty of well-maintained trash and recycling bins, and public education campaigns (including multilingual messages) would make a big difference. I’d also support school programs and local volunteer cleanups, because when kids and families feel ownership of shared spaces, they’re much less likely to treat them like a dump.

I was raised to believe you clean up after yourself and respect the land God gave us, and I still feel that way when I’m out in the park or tending my little garden. I think we need stricter enforcement of existing anti-littering laws with meaningful fines and community service, along with more visible trash and recycling bins so there’s no excuse. Schools and churches should also teach personal responsibility and stewardship of the environment from a young age, so people see not littering as a matter of basic manners and morality, not just a rule.

I think the best way to cut down on litter is a mix of common‑sense rules and real accountability: more trash and recycling bins where people actually need them, clear fines that are actually enforced, and requiring businesses and event organizers to keep the areas around them clean. At the same time, I’d like to see more community clean‑up days and school programs that teach kids to take pride in their neighborhoods—when people feel responsible for a place, they’re less likely to toss their trash on the ground.

As both an artist and an environmental activist, I see littering as a failure of both policy and imagination. The most effective way to prevent it is a combination of strict enforcement with meaningful fines, plentiful and well-designed waste and recycling bins, and publicly funded education that frames clean streets and parks as a shared responsibility. I’d also like to see cities support community-led cleanups and creative public art around waste stations, because when people feel emotionally and visually connected to a place, they’re far less likely to trash it.

As someone who believes we’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, I think strong anti-littering laws with real fines are important, but they’re not enough on their own. We need to teach children and adults alike—through schools, churches, and community programs—that caring for our neighborhoods is a moral responsibility, not just a legal one. Public trash and recycling bins should be easy to find and well-maintained so people have no excuse to toss garbage on the ground. Ultimately, building a culture of personal responsibility and respect for shared spaces will do more than any slogan or campaign alone.

I think the best way to prevent littering is to combine strict rules with real education. There should be more trash and recycling bins in parks, trails, and streets, plus clear fines for people who litter, but also school programs and church groups teaching why caring for the environment is part of respecting God’s creation and our community. If kids grow up seeing their parents and neighbors pick up trash and take pride in clean public spaces, they’re way less likely to litter themselves.

I grew up being taught to respect shared spaces, and it bothers me to see trash thrown around in parks and streets. I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strict enforcement with real fines, plenty of visible trash and recycling bins, and simple public reminders that keeping our communities clean is everyone’s responsibility. Schools and churches can help teach young people to take pride in their neighborhoods, rather than expecting the government to fix everything. Personal responsibility and community standards should come first.

As someone who cares deeply about the environment and tries to live simply and sustainably, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of strong public education, convenient trash and recycling bins, and clear, consistently enforced fines. Cities should run ongoing campaigns, especially in schools and churches, to teach that caring for creation is a moral responsibility, not just a legal one. I also think corporations should be held accountable for excess packaging and waste, so the burden isn’t only on individuals doing the right thing.

At my age, I’ve seen that simply telling people not to litter is far less effective than designing systems that make the right choice the easy choice. We should invest in well‑maintained public infrastructure—plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, frequent collection, and thoughtfully designed public spaces—combined with modest fines that are actually enforced. Just as important, though, is early education and community-based campaigns that frame clean public spaces as a shared civic responsibility; when people feel ownership of their parks and streets, they’re far less likely to treat them as dumping grounds.

Out here, you learn quick that if you don’t take care of the land, it won’t take care of you, and that goes for town streets just as much as cornfields. I think the best way to prevent littering is to enforce the laws we already have with real fines, make sure there are plenty of trash cans around, and teach kids early—at home, in church, and at school—that picking up after yourself is just basic responsibility. Government doesn’t need a fancy new program for this; people need to be held accountable and communities need to take pride in keeping their own places clean.

I think preventing littering is a lot like keeping a good shop—if you don’t have clear rules and some consequences, things get trashed fast. I’d support reasonable fines, plenty of visible trash and recycling cans, and maybe community clean-up days so people see the work it takes to keep a place nice. Government shouldn’t go overboard with surveillance or crazy penalties, but folks ought to take personal responsibility instead of expecting someone else to clean up their mess. In the end, a clean town is like a well-maintained truck: everyone has to do their part or the whole system wears out faster.

As someone who values personal responsibility and orderly communities, I believe the best way to prevent littering is to enforce existing laws with real fines and consequences, not just post polite reminders. Public spaces should be kept clean through a mix of well-placed trash and recycling bins, community clean-up efforts through churches and local groups, and holding individuals accountable when they choose to trash shared areas. I work hard, pay my taxes, and expect people to respect the neighborhoods and parks we all use.

I think the best way to prevent littering is to make it really easy for people to throw things away properly, like having more trash and recycling bins in parks, near schools, and at bus stops. There should also be clear rules and small fines for littering, but schools and communities should focus on teaching kids why keeping our spaces clean matters and organizing clean-up days so we all feel responsible for our town.

I don’t like when people throw trash on the ground because it makes the park and playground look yucky and hurts the animals. My dad and teachers could help us do little clean-up days so everyone learns to keep our places nice and pretty.

As someone who spends a lot of time walking around my community and volunteering at local events, it really frustrates me to see litter piling up in parks and on sidewalks. I’d also support policies that encourage businesses to reduce single-use packaging and help sponsor cleanup efforts, because corporations should share in the responsibility, not just individual residents.

As someone who spends a lot of time out and about and really cares about community spaces, I think the best way to prevent littering is a mix of practical policies and education. I’d especially like to see schools and community groups use tech—like apps or social media challenges—to make cleaning up and proper disposal more visible and rewarding. Keeping public spaces clean shouldn’t just be about punishment; it should feel like a shared responsibility we’re all proud to take on.

Living in a rural area and working with animals every day, I see firsthand how litter can harm wildlife and pollute the land we depend on, so I think we need stricter fines for littering and more consistent enforcement. At the same time, I believe in personal responsibility and community values, so schools, families, and local governments should teach respect for the environment, provide enough trash and recycling bins, and organize clean-up days.

As someone who cares deeply about my community and spends a lot of time outdoors with my family, I believe the best way to prevent littering is a mix of personal responsibility, strong local enforcement, and clear community standards. We should have plenty of trash and recycling bins, visible fines for littering that are actually enforced, and schools and churches teaching kids early on that caring for God’s creation includes keeping our neighborhoods clean.

As someone who values both personal freedom and personal responsibility, I think the best way to prevent littering is to make individuals directly accountable for their own mess—through strict, consistently enforced fines and clear rules, not bloated new programs. I’d pair that with plenty of accessible trash and recycling bins, plus community-driven clean‑up efforts run by volunteers and local groups rather than top‑down mandates. When people see their neighbors taking pride in shared spaces, they’re more likely to respect them.

Working as a cleaner in a residential care facility, I see every day how much better a place feels when it’s kept clean and cared for, and I think our public spaces deserve the same respect. To really prevent littering, we need a mix of strong, consistently enforced fines, plenty of trash and recycling bins, and community-based efforts like volunteer cleanups and public education that help people feel responsible for shared spaces. As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors bird-watching, I’d also support policies that make corporations reduce packaging waste and fund cleanup programs, because individual behavior and corporate responsibility both matter.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors and served in the military, I believe personal responsibility and discipline are key to keeping our public spaces clean. The best policies are strict enforcement of anti-littering laws with real fines, plenty of clearly marked trash and recycling bins, and community-led clean-up efforts that get people personally invested in their neighborhoods. Government should set the rules and enforce them, but it’s on us as citizens to take pride in our surroundings and not treat public spaces like a dumping ground.

Having spent a lifetime studying how ancient societies managed shared spaces, I’m convinced that the most effective way to prevent littering is a combination of strict enforcement and thoughtful design—ample, well-placed bins, clear signage, and meaningful fines that are actually enforced. We should also invest in public education that treats cleanliness as a civic duty rather than mere compliance, emphasizing our responsibility to future generations and to the urban environment we share today.
